title: Mitchells & Butlers promotes Phil Urban to chief executive
text:

Tue, Sep 22, 2015, 08:56 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 34 mins Mitchells & Butlers promotes Phil Urban to chief executive By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 9 minutes ago 0.00 
Mr Urban replaces Alistair Darby, who has run the pub chain since 2012 
Britain’s biggest managed pub and restaurant firm Mitchells & Butlers has appointed Phil Urban as its chief executive, nine months after he joined the FTSE 250 business as its chief operating officer. 
Alistair Darby, who has run the company for the past three years, will step down as chief executive on November 25. 
The appointment came as Mitchells & Butlers (LSE: MAB.L - news ) revealed modest sales growth over the past year, driven by improved food sales . 
In the 50 weeks to September 12, food sales increased by 2.1pc on a like-for-like basis, outweighing the 0.3pc decline in drinks sales. 
As a result overall sales edged up by 1pc. The group said it expected the slow pace of growth to continue, resulting in financial results which were “at the bottom end of the range of current market expectations.” 
In addition to those improvements in the group’s existing sites, Mitchells & Butlers opened 14 new sites and converted another 48 locations. 
That includes 38 of the Orchid pubs that the group acquired in June 2014. These have been turned into branded pubs under names such as Toby Carvery, Ember Inns, Miller & Carter and Harvester. 
Another 40 conversions are planned for next year. 
Chairman Bob Ivell welcomed Mr Urban and thanked Mr Darby for his work at the group. 
"The non-executive directors have considered the issue of the leadership of M&B very carefully and are delighted to announce Phil's appointment. Phil is a strong leader with industry experience and a proven track record of operational delivery, who we are confident will build on the progress made under Alistair,” said Mr Ivell. 
Mr Urban was previously managing director at Grosvenor Casinos; before that he worked in Whitbread’s pub restaurant division , and Scottish and Newcastle Retail’s restaurants and accommodation division. 
He will receive a basic salary of £510,000 as chief executive, while Mr Darby will receive payment of £543,500 in lieu of his one-year notice period. The outgoing boss will be eligible for any bonuses in from this year’s work, but the firm said it does not expect him to hit the threshold for any performance-based payouts (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
